title: Budget 2015: Millions to be hit by insurance price rises
text:
6.50 0.00 
In a surprise move the Chancellor increased the tax on general insurance premiums by more than 50pc 
Millions of British households and businesses will be hit with higher insurance costs following a “stealth” tax rise announced in yesterday’s Budget. 
Chancellor George Osborne revealed that the standard rate of tax paid on insurance premiums, known as Insurance Premium Tax, will rise from 6pc to 9.5pc from November 1, 2015. 
The British Insurance Brokers' Association (BIBA) labelled this a stealth tax rise and claimed it will hit 20.1 million households with contents insurance, 19.6 million with motor insurance and 17 million with buildings insurance. 
The rise will apply to all general insurance products apart from travel insurance, which already comes with a 20pc tax on premiums. Businesses will be hit alongside individuals, as the hike will apply equally to corporate insurance premiums. 
The Association of British Insurers estimates that the new tax rate will add £9.48 to the average annual household insurance policy and £12.25 to the average annual comprehensive motor policy. 
Defending the increase, Mr Osborne said that it would affect just one in five premiums, as other types of insurance such as life and critical illness cover are not affected. He added that the cost of household insurance policies is falling and Britain’s insurance premium tax is well below the rates in many other countries. 
But David Bearman, UK insurance tax expert at EY, said the 50pc tax rise was “unexpected and significant”. 
He warned that it could encourage a number of consumers to “forego buying insurance, which increases their personal risks, and in the case of motor insurance could mean a rise in illegal drivers”. 
The Government estimates that the move will raise an additional £1.5bn a year for the Treasury. 
Nicholas and Fabienne d’Adhemar, who live in Fulham, south-west London, recently sold their two-bedroom flat and bought a large family home to accommodate their growing family. 
Mrs (LSE: MRS.L - news ) d’Adhemar, who works for a London law firm, said the cost of buying a property is high enough without the added pressure of increased home insurance premiums. 
“When you’re moving up the property ladder you tend to really stretch yourself to the maximum financially. To then find that the cost of your house and contents insurance is increasing on top is an extra financial burden that many families will struggle with. An increase of 3.5pc is not an insignificant amount. 
“The fact that other types of insurance such as motor cover will also suffer the same increase just adds to the growing list of expenses that families are being forced to factor into their budgets.”
